title: 109_s3703
content: The Act titled "Medicare Prescription Drug Lifeline Act of 2006" allows individuals entering the Medicare coverage gap to switch to a plan that provides coverage in the gap. The Act allows individuals to switch to a plan that covers part D drugs after reaching the initial coverage limit but before the annual out-of-pocket threshold, within 30 days of enactment. The Act permits individuals to enroll in a prescription drug plan outside their region if no plan in their region covers brand name part D drugs after reaching the initial coverage limit but before the annual out-of-pocket threshold. The Secretary will determine the region for enrollment in such a plan. The Act allows individuals to enroll in a prescription drug plan outside their region if no plan in their region covers brand name part D drugs after reaching the initial coverage limit but before the annual out-of-pocket threshold. The Secretary will notify applicable individuals of the option to change plans within 30 days of meeting the definition of such an individual. The process established for plan changes will remain in effect through December 31, 2006. The Act allows individuals enrolled in a prescription drug plan or MA-PD plan to switch plans if their current plan does not cover part D drugs after reaching the initial coverage limit but before the annual out-of-pocket threshold. The terms "prescription drug plan" and "MA-PD plan" are defined in the Social Security Act. GAO will conduct a study and report on the elimination of the Medicare Part D coverage gap. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the costs and adjustments needed to eliminate the initial coverage limit in Medicare Part D without increasing program costs. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress by May 1, 2007, with recommendations on eliminating the initial coverage limit in Medicare Part D without increasing program costs.
